Award.AwardTitle: Dynamics, Plasticity and Evolvability of bacterial small regulatory RNAs

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Small RNAs, the recent addition to the repertoire of genetic regulators, play central roles in key biological processes in bacteria, plants and animals. Quantitative understanding of the regulatory properties of small RNAs, how molecular and cellular processes influence them, and how they can adapt and evolve, is key to understanding the design principles and evolution of regulatory networks. In this project the PI will study how properties of small regulatory RNA and their target mRNAs affect the efficiency, noise features, and evolvability of RNA regulation. Such properties include molecular features of sequence and structure, and functional properties such as translation rate and stability. Quantitative experiments and theoretical studies will be employed synergistically to bridge multiple scales, from the molecular level to cellular functionality and evolutionary dynamics. The results of this study are expected to shed new light on the role played by small RNAs in various pathways and to provide tools that map sequence data into properties of small RNA - target interaction and its evolution.

Broader Impact. This project bridges between molecular biophysics and quantitative biology, and exemplifies a true inter-disciplinary approach. It is expected to be of interest to young researchers from a wide range of disciplines, and the PI will provide an opportunity for students to experience this type of research by establishing a discussion group that would follow the project. The PI is developing a new course intended for advanced undergraduate and graduate students, which will discuss a spectrum of biological systems from a quantitative perspective, and develop the theoretical and practical aspects of modeling complex biological systems. Small RNA regulation will serve as a central theme in this course.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During their life bacteria experience drastic changes in their surrounding as they migrate from one environment to another, colonize a host, or get exposed to chemicals or antibiotics. To survive and compete in changing environments, bacteria regulate the expression of their genes to execute molecular programs of response and adaptation. In the last two decades it had become clear that one major overlooked mechanism of biological regulation relies on RNA molecules, previously considered mostly as intermediates between genes and proteins. Regulatory RNAs have been found to play central role in the ability of bacteria to cope with stress, to regulate metabolism, to become virulent and to cause disease. Regulatory RNA molecule are often small, encoded by a short sequence and forming a compact molecular structure. 

We are interested in the ways by which the sequence and structure of a small RNA determins its functional properties, its efficiency and its specificity, within the complex biological environment. The research supported by this award was designed to address this question using a combination of theoretical, computational and experimental methodologies. The results of our studies gave us a number of new insights into the way small RNAs are shaped by evolution to function effectively in the cell. In particular, we learned that small RNAs have a modular design that permits tuning of their efficiency and their specificity. Surprisingly we found  that the very same machinery responsible for translating RNA molecules into proteins is also involved in promoting its potential to be shut-down by regulatory RNAs. Small RNAs act together in the cellular regulatory network, and we discovered that the many genes targeted by a small RNA act together to yield a robust molecular response in the face of fluctuating environments. We also showed that organisms take different control strategies to regulated different functions to make regulation both productive and efficient. 

Our results are important for understanding the role and action of small RNAs involved in mechanisms that lead to infection and disease, as well as small RNAs involved in control of metabolism in probiotic bacteria. Within the developing field of synthetic biology, such basic knowledge can be translated into theraputic or metabolic engineering strategies. In the course of our studies we developed computational tools and theoretical models that will be useful for the development of such approaches and for future studies of biological regulation in bacteria and other organisms. 

The research supported by this award integrates multiple disciplines and exemplifies the use of quantitative modeling and computational studies in the design and interpretation of experiments. We have used aspects of this research to develop teaching materials to train the future generation of inter-disciplinary scientists. As part of our educational mission we invovled young researchers from multiple disciplines and from under-represented groups in this project.
